content.p: The term “3D” means 3-dimensional.
The term “3D elevation data” means 3D, high-resolution data obtained using LiDAR, IfSAR, or other methods over the United States (including territories).
The term “3D elevation data” includes terrestrial and bathymetric elevation data.
The term “3D Elevation Program” means the 3D Elevation Program established under section 3104(a) of this title.
The term “IfSAR” means interferometric synthetic aperture radar.
The term “Indian tribe” has the meaning given the term in section 5304 of title 25.

paragraph.heading: Lahar
paragraph.chapeau: The term “lahar” means a large debris flow of mostly volcanic material that is—

subparagraph.content: a hazard in watersheds downstream of volcanic peaks.

content.p: The term “LiDAR” means light detection and ranging.
The term “Secretary” means the Secretary of the Interior, acting through the Director of the United States Geological Survey.

paragraph.heading: State office
paragraph.chapeau: The term “State office” means any unit of State government that handles the identification, mapping, assessment, and research of landslide hazards or responding to landslide events, including—

subparagraph.content: a State department of emergency response; and
the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands;
the Republic of the Marshall Islands;

subsection.heading: Establishment
subsection.chapeau: The Secretary shall establish a program, to be known as the “National Landslide Hazards Reduction Program” (referred to in this section as the “program”)—

paragraph.content: to identify and understand landslide hazards and risks;
to protect communities at risk of landslide hazards; and
to help improve communication and emergency preparedness, including by coordinating with communities and entities responsible for infrastructure that are at risk of landslide hazards.

paragraph.heading: Program activities
paragraph.chapeau: The Secretary, in coordination with the Interagency Coordinating Committee on Landslide Hazards established by subsection (c)(1) (referred to in this section as the “Committee”) and in coordination with existing activities of the United States Geological Survey and other Federal agencies, shall—

subparagraph.content: identify, map, assess, and research landslide hazards;

subparagraph.chapeau: in coordination with State offices, units of local government, territories, and Indian tribes—

clause.content: establish working groups with State offices, units of local government, territories, and Indian tribes to identify regional and local priorities for researching, identifying, mapping, and assessing landslide hazards; and

clause.chapeau: develop and implement landslide hazard guidelines for—

subclause.content: geologists;
geological and geotechnical engineers;
emergency management personnel; and
land use and other decisionmakers.

paragraph.heading: National strategy
paragraph.chapeau: Not later than 1 year after January 5, 2021, and every 5 years thereafter, the Secretary, in coordination with the Committee, shall develop and publish a national strategy for landslide hazards, risk reduction, and response in the United States (including territories), which shall include—

subparagraph.content: goals and priorities for the program;
priorities for data acquisition, research, communications, and risk management on landslides and landslide hazards across relevant Federal agencies; and

a detailed interagency plan, which shall take into consideration national disaster preparedness, response, and recovery frameworks, to carry out the national strategy, including details about the programs, projects, and budgets that will be used to implement the national strategy.

paragraph.heading: National landslide hazards database
paragraph.chapeau: In carrying out the program, the Secretary, in coordination with State offices, units of local government, territories, and Indian tribes, shall develop and maintain a publicly accessible national landslide hazard and risk inventory database to compile, maintain, standardize, and evaluate data regarding—

clause.content: health and safety;
the economy and infrastructure; and
the environment;

paragraph.heading: Landslide hazard and risk preparedness for communities
paragraph.chapeau: In carrying out the program, the Secretary, in coordination with the Secretary of the Army, the Secretary of Commerce, the Secretary of Homeland Security, the Secretary of Transportation, and the heads of other relevant Federal agencies, and in consultation with State offices, units of local government, territories, and Indian tribes, shall develop and disseminate—

subparagraph.chapeau: landslide planning and risk reduction guidance, guidelines, maps, tools, and training materials to help inform State, territorial, local, and Tribal governments and decisionmakers with respect to—

clause.content: the use and implementation of landslide hazard assessments;
the applied use of the database developed under paragraph (3);
reducing losses from landslides; and
resources available for communities working to improve landslide hazard preparedness; and

subparagraph.chapeau: landslide preparedness curricula and training modules for—

clause.content: State, territorial, local, and Tribal officials;
Federal, State, territorial, local, and Tribal emergency managers; and
the National Guard.

paragraph.heading: Debris flow early warning system
paragraph.chapeau: In carrying out the program, the Secretary, in coordination with the Secretary of Commerce and the Secretary of Homeland Security, shall expand the early warning system for debris flow by—

subparagraph.content: expanding the early warning system for post-wildfire debris flow to include recently burned areas across the western United States;
developing procedures with State, territorial, local, and Tribal governments to monitor stormwater drainage in areas with high debris flow risk; and
identifying high-risk debris flow areas, such as recently burned land and potential lahar hazard areas.

paragraph.heading: Emergency response activities
paragraph.chapeau: In carrying out the program, the Secretary, in coordination with the Secretary of Commerce, the Secretary of Homeland Security, the heads of other relevant Federal agencies, States offices, units of local government, territories, and Indian tribes, shall establish and support emergency response procedures for the rapid deployment of Federal scientists, equipment, and services to areas impacted by a significant landslide event—

subparagraph.content: to support emergency response efforts and improve the safety of emergency responders;
to conduct research to advance the understanding of the causes, impacts, and reduction of landslide hazards and risks.

subsection.heading: Interagency Coordinating Committee on Landslide Hazards

content.p: There is established a committee, to be known as the “Interagency Coordinating Committee on Landslide Hazards”.

paragraph.heading: Membership
paragraph.chapeau: The Committee shall be composed of the following members (or their designees):

subparagraph.content: The Secretary, who shall serve as Chairperson of the Committee.
The Director of the National Science Foundation.
The Director of the Office of Science and Technology Policy.
The Director of the Office of Management and Budget.

content.p: The Committee shall meet at the call of the Chairperson.

subparagraph.content: facilitate communication and coordination across Federal agencies in the planning, management, budgeting, and execution of landslide activities; and

subparagraph.chapeau: support the development and execution of the national strategy under subsection (b)(2), including by—

clause.content: supporting the development of national goals and priorities for the national strategy;
articulating Federal agency roles, responsibilities, and resources for carrying out the national strategy; and
overseeing the implementation of the national strategy.

content.p: The Secretary shall establish an advisory committee, to be known as the “Advisory Committee on Landslides” (referred to in this subsection as the “Advisory Committee”).

paragraph.heading: Membership
paragraph.chapeau: The Advisory Committee shall be composed of not fewer than 11 members—

subparagraph.content: of whom none may be an individual described in any of subparagraphs (A) through (F) of section 7342(a)(1) of title 5; and

clause.content: States, including State geological organizations;
territories, including territorial geological organizations;
Indian tribes, including Tribal geological organizations;

clause.chapeau: research institutions and institutions of higher education that are qualified—

subclause.content: to provide advice regarding landslide hazard and risk reduction; and
to represent related scientific, architectural, engineering, and planning disciplines;

clause.content: industry standards development organizations; and
State, territorial, local, and Tribal emergency management agencies.

subparagraph.heading: In general
subparagraph.chapeau: The Advisory Committee shall submit to the Committee recommendations for the implementation of the program, including recommendations regarding—

clause.content: landslide hazard and risk reduction and planning;
tools for communities;
research; and
such other topics as the Advisory Committee determines appropriate.

content.p: The Secretary and the agency heads described in subparagraphs (B) through (I) of subsection (c)(2) shall take into consideration any recommendation of the Advisory Committee submitted under subparagraph (A).

paragraph.heading: Cooperative landslide hazard mapping and assessment program

subparagraph.heading: In general
subparagraph.chapeau: Subject to appropriations, the Secretary may—

clause.content: provide grants, on a competitive basis, to State, territorial, local, and Tribal governments to research, map, assess, and collect data on landslide hazards within the jurisdictions of those governments; and
accept and use funds received from other Federal and non-Federal partners to advance the purposes of the program.

content.p: The Secretary shall consult annually with the Committee, States, units of local government, territories, and Indian tribes to establish priorities for the grant program under this paragraph.

clause.heading: Funding prioritization
clause.chapeau: In providing grants under this paragraph, the Secretary shall give priority to projects—

subclause.content: that will achieve the greatest landslide hazard and risk reduction;
that reflect the goals and priorities of the national strategy established under subsection (b)(2)(A);
not less than 50 percent of the total cost of which is matched by non-Federal sources; and
that include acquisition of enhanced elevation data consistent with the 3D Elevation Program.

subparagraph.heading: Requirement
subparagraph.chapeau: If the Secretary elects to provide grants under subparagraph (A)(i), the Secretary shall publish on a publicly available website a description of—

clause.content: the grants; and
the findings made from those grants.

subparagraph.heading: In general
subparagraph.chapeau: To advance the goals and priorities of the national strategy established under subsection (b)(2)(A), subject to appropriations, the Director of the National Science Foundation (referred to in this paragraph as the “Director”) may provide grants to eligible entities for landslide research, including research on—

clause.content: the causes, mechanisms, triggers, hydrology, and geology of landslides;
ways to reduce landslide hazards and risks to minimize loss of life and property, including landslide hazard and risk communication, perception, decisionmaking, tools, and technologies; and
other goals and priorities of the national strategy established under subsection (b)(2)(A).

content.p: The Director shall determine whether an entity is eligible to receive a grant under this paragraph.

subparagraph.heading: Requirements
subparagraph.chapeau: In providing grants under this paragraph, the Director shall—

clause.content: ensure that the grants are provided on a competitive basis;
consider grant applications submitted by eligible entities that have developed the application in partnership with 1 or more State geological surveys; and

clause.chapeau: publish on a publicly available website a description of—

subclause.content: the grants; and
the findings made from those grants.

subsection.heading: Biennial report
subsection.chapeau: Through calendar year 2030, the Secretary shall submit to Congress a biennial report, including a description of, with respect to the 2-calendar-year period preceding the date of the report—

paragraph.content: the goals and accomplishments of the Committee in carrying out the national strategy developed under subsection (b)(2);
the results of the activities of the Committee under this section; and
the extent to which any recommendations of the Advisory Committee under subsection (d)(3)(A) have been implemented.

subsection.heading: Significant events
subsection.chapeau: Not later than 1 year after a significant landslide event in the United States (including territories) occurs, the Secretary shall publish on a publicly available website—

paragraph.content: a description of the landslide event and the implications of the event on communities, including life and property;
recommendations on how the identification of the landslide risk could have been improved prior to the event;
a description of the effectiveness of any warning and risk communication, including the dissemination of warnings by State, territorial, local, and Tribal partners in the affected area;
recommendations to improve risk identification, reduction, and communication to landowners and units of local government;
recommendations to improve landslide hazard preparedness and emergency response activities under this section; and
such other findings as the Secretary determines appropriate.

subsection.heading: Funding
subsection.chapeau: For each of fiscal years 2021 through 2024—

paragraph.content: there is authorized to be appropriated to the United States Geological Survey, $25,000,000 to carry out this section;
there is authorized to be appropriated to the National Science Foundation, $11,000,000 to carry out this section; and
there is authorized to be appropriated to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, $1,000,000 to carry out this section.

content.p: Funds to carry out the activities under this section shall be derived from amounts authorized to be appropriated that are enacted after the date of the enactment of this section.

As the Secretary determines to be appropriate and subject to appropriations, the Secretary, through existing programs, shall advance the identification, mapping, research, and monitoring of subsidence and groundwater resource accounting, particularly in areas affected by drought.

paragraph.heading: In general
paragraph.chapeau: The Secretary shall establish a program, to be known as the “3D Elevation Program”—

subparagraph.content: to provide 3D elevation data coverage for the United States;
to coordinate and facilitate the collection, dissemination, and use of 3D elevation data among Federal departments and agencies and non-Federal entities;
to produce standard, publicly accessible 3D elevation data products for the United States; and

subparagraph.chapeau: to promote the collection, dissemination, and use of 3D elevation data among Federal, State, local, and Tribal governments, communities, institutions of higher education, and the private sector through—

clause.content: cooperative agreements;
the development and maintenance of spatial data infrastructure to provide quality control and deliver to the public 3D elevation data products;

in coordination with the 3D Elevation Federal Interagency Coordinating Committee established under subsection (b), States, and industry and standards bodies, the development of standards and guidelines for 3D elevation data acquisition to increase accessibility to 3D elevation data in a standard, easy-to-use format; and
the identification, assessment, and adoption of emerging technologies to improve the accuracy and efficiency of the 3D Elevation Program.

subparagraph.heading: In general
subparagraph.chapeau: The Secretary shall manage the 3D Elevation Program—

clause.content: to ensure efficiency with respect to related activities of the Department of the Interior and other participating Federal departments and agencies; and
to meet the needs of Department of the Interior programs, stakeholders, and the public.

subparagraph.heading: Other Federal departments and agencies
subparagraph.chapeau: The head of each Federal department and agency involved in the acquisition, production, distribution, or application of 3D elevation data shall—

clause.content: coordinate with the 3D Elevation Federal Interagency Coordinating Committee established under subsection (b) to acquire additional, enhanced 3D elevation data;
submit to the Secretary a description of priority areas of interest for 3D elevation data collection for use in providing grants and cooperative agreements under subsection (d);
implement policies and procedures for data acquisition and sharing that are consistent with standards and guidelines developed under the 3D Elevation Program;
participate in, and share the results and benefits of, the 3D Elevation Program, in accordance with standards and guidelines developed under the 3D Elevation Program; and

clause.chapeau: ensure that any 3D elevation data acquired with Federal grant funding—

subclause.content: meets 3D Elevation Program standards; and
is included in the national holdings of those data.

content.p: The Secretary, in coordination with the Secretary of Commerce and the Secretary of Homeland Security, shall establish an interagency coordinating committee, to be known as the “3D Elevation Federal Interagency Coordinating Committee” (referred to in this subsection as the “Committee”), to better coordinate 3D elevation data management across the Federal Government.

paragraph.heading: Membership
paragraph.chapeau: The Committee shall be composed of the following members (or their designees):

subparagraph.content: The Secretary, who shall serve as Chairperson of the Committee.
The Director of the National Science Foundation.
The Director of the Office of Science and Technology Policy.
The Director of the Office of Management and Budget.
The head of any other Federal department or agency, at the request of the Secretary.

paragraph.heading: Coordination
paragraph.chapeau: The Committee shall coordinate, as appropriate, with the existing activities of—

content.p: The Committee shall meet at the call of the Chairperson.

subparagraph.content: oversee the planning, management, and coordination of the 3D Elevation Program; and

subparagraph.chapeau: develop, by not later than 1 year after January 5, 2021, and update periodically thereafter—

clause.content: a strategic plan that establishes goals and priorities for activities carried out under the 3D Elevation Program; and
a detailed management plan to implement the strategic plan.

subsection.heading: Subcommittee of National Geospatial Advisory Committee

content.p: The Secretary shall establish, within the National Geospatial Advisory Committee, a subcommittee (referred to in this subsection as the “Subcommittee”).

clause.content: consist of not fewer than 11 members, of whom none may be a Federal officer or employee; and

subclause.content: research and academic institutions;
industry standards development organizations;
units of State and local government; and
the private sector.

subparagraph.heading: Assessment
subparagraph.chapeau: The Subcommittee shall conduct an assessment of—

subclause.content: the collection, dissemination, and use of 3D elevation data; and
science and technology relating to 3D elevation data;

clause.content: the effectiveness of the 3D Elevation Program in carrying out the activities described in subsection (a)(1);
the need to revise or reorganize the 3D Elevation Program; and
the management, coordination, implementation, and activities of the 3D Elevation Program.

subparagraph.heading: Report
subparagraph.chapeau: Not later than 1 year after January 5, 2021, and every 2 years thereafter, the Subcommittee shall submit to the Secretary and the 3D Elevation Federal Interagency Coordinating Committee established under subsection (b) a report that includes—

clause.content: the findings of the assessment under subparagraph (A); and
recommendations of the Subcommittee based on those findings, if any.

content.p: The Secretary may make grants and enter into cooperative agreements with other Federal departments and agencies, units of State, local, or Tribal government, institutions of higher education, nonprofit research institutions, or other organizations to facilitate the improvement of nationwide coverage of 3D elevation data.

To be eligible to receive a grant or enter into a cooperative agreement under this subsection, an entity described in paragraph (1) shall submit to the Secretary an application at such time, in such manner, and containing such information as the Secretary may require.

A grant or cooperative agreement under this subsection shall be subject to such terms and conditions as the Secretary determines to be appropriate, including making data publically available and interoperable with other Federal datasets.
For each of fiscal years 2021 through 2024, there is authorized to be appropriated to the Secretary $40,000,000 to carry out this section.
Funds to carry out the activities under this section shall be derived from amounts authorized to be appropriated to the Secretary that are enacted after January 5, 2021.
